{{Infobox court case}} '''''Ellen Pao v. Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers LLC and DOES 1-20''''' is a lawsuit filed in 2012 in [[San Francisco County Superior Court]] under the [[law of California]] by executive [[Ellen Pao]] for [[gender discrimination]] against her employer, [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]]. Overlapping with a number of condemning studies on the representation of women in venture capital, the case was followed closely by reporters, advocacy groups and Silicon Valley executives.<ref name="senior-4-100" /> Given the tendency for similar cases to reach settlements out of court, coverage of ''Pao v. Kleiner Perkins'' described it as a landmark trial once it began in February 2015.<ref name="NYTDisrupter" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/18/whats-at-stake-in-the-ellen-pao-case/|title=What's at Stake in the Ellen Pao Case|first=Liz|last=Gannes|publisher=Recode|date=2015-02-18|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref> On March 27, 2015 the jury found in favor of Kleiner Perkins on all counts.
==Background==
===Ellen Pao=== {{main|Ellen Pao}} [[File:Ellen Pao 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ellen Pao]], the plaintiff, in 2015]] Ellen Pao is a [[Chinese American]] woman from New Jersey.<ref name="pao">{{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/11/ellen-pao-who-sued-kleiner-perkins-joins-reddit/ | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | first=David | last=Streitfeld | title=Ellen Pao, Who Sued Kleiner Perkins, Joins Reddit | date=April 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name = Reddit>{{cite news| url=http://fortune.com/2013/04/11/ellen-pao-has-landed-at-reddit/ | work=Fortune | title=Ellen Pao has landed ... at Reddit | first=Dan | last=Primack | date=April 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Fortune /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/03/17/ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins-china-singtao-daily-journal-ktsf/24905541/|title=Ellen Pao trial is big news in China|author= Weise, Elizabeth |date=March 17, 2015|work=USA Today}}</ref> She has a bachelor's degree in [[Electrical Engineering]] from [[Princeton University]], a [[juris doctor]] from [[Harvard Law School]] and an MBA from [[Harvard Business School]].<ref name=pao/><ref name=Fortune />
From 1994 to 1996, Pao worked as a [[corporate attorney]] at [[Cravath, Swaine & Moore]]. In 1998, Pao worked at [[MSN TV|WebTV]].<ref name="recode9">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/09/liveblog-as-ellen-pao-takes-the-stand-the-test-now-is-likability/|title=Liveblog: As Ellen Pao Takes the Stand, the Test Now Is Likability|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-09|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> Pao worked at several companies in [[Silicon Valley]] including [[BEA Systems]] as Senior Director, Corporate Business Development from 2001 until 2005.<ref name=Fortune /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/ellen-pao|title=Ellen Pao|work=crunchbase.com}}</ref>
In 2005 Pao joined Kleiner Perkins as technical chief of staff for [[John Doerr]], a senior partner, a job that required degrees in engineering, law, and business, and experience in enterprise software.<ref name=Fortune /> In 2007 she became a junior investing partner with Ted Schlein as her boss<ref name="recode.net">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/23/a-whos-who-of-the-kleiner-perkins-ellen-pao-trial/|title=A Who's Who of the Kleiner Perkins-Ellen Pao Trial|first=Noah|last=Kulwin|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-23|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref><ref name="recode-ep2">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/10/liveblog-day-two-of-ellen-pao-on-the-stand/|title=Liveblog: Day Two of Ellen Pao on the Stand|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-10|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> but was eventually passed over for a senior partner position. According to Pao, she had the job title of junior partner from her date of hiring<ref name = PaoPlea >7th allegation, page 4 [https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/1672582/pao-complaint.pdf Complaint of Pao]</ref> and was promised an opportunity to move into an investing role.<ref name=recodevoice>[http://recode.net/2015/03/10/ellen-paos-testimony-making-sure-her-story-is-told/ "Ellen Pao: ‘I Wanted to Make Sure My Story Was Told’" March 10, 2015] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312003545/http://recode.net/2015/03/10/ellen-paos-testimony-making-sure-her-story-is-told/ |date=March 12, 2015 }} Re/code accessed March 12, 2015</ref> Doerr, who has expressed awareness of the gender gap at venture capital firms, [[Mentorship|mentored]] Pao, liberally providing feedback, but, in the end, agreed with the other senior partners who had made negative evaluations of her work at the firm. It was Pao's contention that men with similar profiles were, nevertheless, promoted.<ref name=Forbes03415>{{cite news|author1=Ellen Huet|title=Kleiner Perkins's John Doerr And Ellen Pao: A Mentorship Sours|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ellenhuet/2015/03/04/kleiner-perkinss-john-doerr-and-ellen-pao-a-mentorship-sours/|accessdate=March 6, 2015|work=Forbes|date=March 4, 2015|quote=Mr. Schlein and all the other digital partners felt that way, except me. I saw it differently.}}</ref>
On May 10, 2012, Pao filed a gender discrimination lawsuit against her employer<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/22/kleiner-discrimination-idUSL1E8GMAJS20120522 | title=Kleiner gender discrimination suit | accessdate=May 24, 2012 | work=Reuters | date=May 22, 2012}}</ref> alleging [[Organizational retaliatory behavior#Workplace retaliation|workplace retaliation]] by a married junior partner, Ajit Nazre, with whom she had an affair.<ref name=NYT03515>{{cite news|author1=David Streitfeld|title=In Ellen Pao's Suit vs. Kleiner Perkins, World of Venture Capital Is Under Microscope|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/06/technology/in-ellen-paos-suit-vs-kleiner-perkins-world-of-venture-capital-is-under-microscope.html|accessdate=March 6, 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 5, 2015}}</ref> She planned to continue working at the firm but left on October 1 claiming that she was terminated.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/05/ellen-pao-quora-speaks-still-at-kleiner-perkins-quora/|title=Ellen Pao Breaks Her Silence: I'm Still At Kleiner Perkins, And I Don't Plan On Leaving|first=Colleen|last=Taylor|publisher=TechCrunch|date=2012-06-05|accessdate=2015-10-12}}</ref><ref name = Complaint >[https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/1672582/pao-complaint.pdf Complaint of Ellen Pao]</ref> Her lawyer said she was fired in retaliation for her lawsuit and the complaint was amended to add that cause of action.<ref name = Complaint />
Pao joined [[Reddit]] in 2013 and became interim CEO in November 2014 after [[Yishan Wong]] resigned.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Altman|first1=Sam|title=A new team at reddit|url=http://blog.samaltman.com/a-new-team-at-reddit|website=Sam Altman|accessdate=November 13, 2014}}</ref>
===Kleiner Perkins=== {{main|Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers}} Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is a [[venture capital firm]] located in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]] in [[Silicon Valley]]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and other media have called it one of the "largest and most established" venture capital firms<ref name="Austin">{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2010/01/22/one-of-these-venture-capital-firms-is-not-like-the-other/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=One Of These Venture Firms Is Not Like The Other | first=Scott | last=Austin | date=2010-01-22}}</ref> and it has been called "one of Silicon Valley's top venture capital providers" by "Dealbook".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/03/gores-dual-role-in-spotlight-advocate-and-investor/ | work=The New York Times (Dealbook)| title=Gore's Dual Role in Spotlight: Advocate and Investor | date=3 November 2009}}</ref>
The firm specializes in investments in incubation and early stage companies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=21381 |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |title=Capital Markets: Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers |accessdate=27 July 2011}}</ref> Since its founding in 1972, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has backed entrepreneurs in more than 500 ventures including [[AOL]], [[Amazon.com]], [[Navigenics]], [[Citrix]], [[Compaq]], [[Electronic Arts]], [[Genentech]], Genomic Health, [[Geron Corporation]],<ref name="yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com">{{cite web|title=SEC Schedule 13G, filed Feb. 17, 1999|url= http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/DisplayFiling.aspx?TabIndex=2&FilingID=1363847&companyid=11441&ppu=%252fDefault.aspx%253fcompanyid%253d11441%2526amp%253bformtypeID%253d346}}</ref> [[Google]], [[Intuit]], [[Juniper Networks]], [[Nebula (company)|Nebula]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Timothy Prickett|title=NASA's former CTO launches Nebula cloud controller|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/07/27/nebula_openstack_cloud_controller/print.html|publisher=The Register|accessdate=12 March 2013}}</ref> [[Netscape]], [[Sun Microsystems]], [[Symantec]], [[Verisign]], [[WebMD]] and [[Zynga]]. KPCB focuses its global investments in three practice areas – digital, green tech and life sciences.<ref>[http://www.kpcb.com/portfolio/ KPCB Portfolio Companies]</ref>
Although there are fewer women than men in both junior and senior positions employed by Kleiner Perkins, its gender gap is smaller than that of most other venture capital firms and its most prominent female partner, [[Mary Meeker]], has called it "the best place to be for a woman in the business."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/3/17/8228649/mary-meeker-ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins|title=The 'Queen of the Internet' defends Kleiner Perkins in gender discrimination trial|first=Nitasha|last=Tiku|publisher=The Verge|date=2015-03-17|accessdate=2015-10-05}}</ref>
Representatives for Kleiner Perkins stated that they had offered Pao a five-month transition, with pay, to an [[management|operating role]],<ref name = liveblog4 >{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/12/liveblog-day-four-of-ellen-pao-on-the-stand/|title=Liveblog: Day Four of Ellen Pao on the Stand|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-12|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> and only fired her effective October 31, 2012 when she rejected the offer.<ref name = DefendentBrief >Section D page 6 [https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/1672504/kleinertrialbrief.pdf Trial brief Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]</ref> They claimed that the decision to reassign her was made for performance reasons unrelated to the lawsuit.<ref name=Fortune>{{cite news|last1=Lashinsky|first1=Adam|last2=Benner|first2=Katie|title=A tale of money, sex and power: The Ellen Pao and Buddy Fletcher affair|url=http://fortune.com/2012/10/25/a-tale-of-money-sex-and-power-the-ellen-pao-and-buddy-fletcher-affair/|work=[[Fortune Magazine]]|date=October 25, 2012|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/ELLEN-PAO-S-LAWYER-Kleiner-Perkins-Just-Fired-3916859.php |title=Ellen Pao's Lawyer: Kleiner Perkins Just Fired Her—And We're Filing A Wrongful-Termination Complaint |work=The San Francsico Chronicle |first=Owen |last=Thomas |date=October 3, 2012 |accessdate=October 4, 2012|quote=Because of longstanding issues having no relationship or bearing on the litigation, Kleiner approached Ms. Pao to facilitate her transition, over an extended period of time, out of the firm. The proposed terms, that did not require Ms. Pao to waive any legal rights or claims, are generous, fair and intended to support Ms. Pao in a successful career transition.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2012/10/03/ellen-pao-leaving-kleiner-perkins-remains-on-payroll/ |title=Ellen Pao Leaving Kleiner Perkins, Remains on Payroll |work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Deborah |last=Gage |date=October 3, 2012 |accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref>
==Causes of action== The original case was filed under the [[California Fair Employment and Housing Act]] and contained three causes of action:<ref name="Complaint"/>
*Employment discrimination based on gender:
{{quote|12940. It is an unlawful employment practice, unless based upon a bona fide occupational qualification, or, except where based upon applicable security regulations established by the United States or the State of California: (a) For an employer, because of the race, religious creed, color, national origin, ancestry, physical disability, mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, marital status, sex, gender, gender identity, gender expression, age, sexual orientation, or military and veteran status of any person, to refuse to hire or employ the person or to refuse to select the person for a training program leading to employment, or to bar or to discharge the person from employment or from a training program leading to employment, or to discriminate against the person in compensation or in terms, conditions, or privileges of employment.<ref name = 12940etseq >[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=gov&group=12001-13000&file=12940-12951 GOVERNMENT CODE SECTION 12940-12951]</ref>}}
*Workplace retaliation:
{{quote|(h) For any employer, labor organization, employment agency, or person to discharge, expel, or otherwise discriminate against any person because the person has opposed any practices forbidden under this part or because the person has filed a complaint, testified, or assisted in any proceeding under this part.<ref name = 12940etseq />}}
*Failure to take reasonable steps to prevent gender discrimination:
{{quote|(k) For an employer, labor organization, employment agency, apprenticeship training program, or any training program leading to employment, to fail to take all reasonable steps necessary to prevent discrimination and harassment from occurring.<ref name = 12940etseq />}}
Following her termination the complaint was amended and a second count of retaliation, termination, was added.<ref name = Complaint /> The [[actual damages]] demanded by the suit totalled $16 million. This is approximately the amount that Pao floated in a conversation with COO Eric Keller when asked what it would take to change her mind about staying at the company. Pao explained that she "wanted my payment to be enough so it was a meaningful amount to Kleiner Perkins, so they saw it would be painful to not fix problems."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/kleiner-attacks-pao-stand-resentful-greedy/|title=Kleiner attacks Pao on the stand as resentful and greedy|first=Davey|last=Alba|publisher=Wired|date=2015-03-12|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> The plaintiff also made a plea for [[punitive damages]].<ref name = PDRECODE >[http://recode.net/2015/03/17/judge-says-pao-needs-to-do-better-to-prove-case-for-punitive-damages/ "Judge Says Pao Needs to Do Better to Prove Case for Punitive Damages"] Liz Gannes ''Re/code'' March 17, 2015, accessed March 18, 2015</ref> Although Judge Harold Kahn initially leaned toward denying this motion, he approved it on March 21, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/3/21/8267273/judge-in-kleiner-perkins-trial-just-ruled-that|title=Ellen Pao can sue Kleiner Perkins for punitive damages, rules judge|first=Nitasha|last=Tiku|publisher=The Verge|date=2015-03-21|accessdate=2015-10-05}}</ref>
==Trial== The matter went to trial in late February 2015 with [[jury selection]] on Monday, February 23, and [[opening statement]]s on Tuesday, February 24.<ref name=recode022415>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes|title=Venture Capitalist Trae Vassallo to Testify She Was Harassed by Same Partner as Ellen Pao|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/24/venture-capitalist-trae-vassallo-to-testify-she-was-harassed-by-same-partner-as-ellen-pao/|accessdate=March 7, 2015|work=Re/code|date=February 24, 2015}}</ref> The trial, lasting 24 days, resulted in a verdict for Kleiner Perkins.<ref name=NYT032715/> It was covered by the national media and elicited broad comment regarding the issues raised.<ref name=NYT03615>{{cite news|author1=Claire Cain Miller|title=A Racy Silicon Valley Lawsuit, and More Subtle Questions About Sex Discrimination|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/07/upshot/a-racy-silicon-valley-lawsuit-and-more-subtle-questions-about-sex-discrimination.html|accessdate=March 7, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 6, 2015|format=Upshot blog|quote=the real drama is in the more mundane charges, about slights familiar to any woman in any workplace that are rarely aired in public, much less in a courtroom.}}</ref> The case was live blogged and [[Twitter|tweeted]], to the point that the constant coverage provided both humorous and serious feedback to lawyers and witnesses.<ref name=recodemedia32515>{{cite news|author1=Nellie Bowles and Liz Gannes|title=Lawyers Reading Mean Tweets: How the Media Influenced the Ellen Pao Trial|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/26/lawyers-reading-mean-tweets-how-the-media-influenced-the-ellen-pao-trial/|accessdate=March 26, 2015|work=Re/code|date=March 26, 2015|quote=In this historic and high profile case, the media coverage has had a strangely powerful influence on the court proceedings. Though the jury may have to live in a self-imposed media-free vacuum, the judge, lawyers and witnesses do not. They're glued to the press. Trials do not often get this much attention. The lawyers follow each story carefully.}}</ref>
The trial was heard before a jury<ref name=Fortune03515>{{cite news|author1=Shalene Gupta|title=Meet the jury that will decide Silicon Valley's biggest sex bias case|url=http://fortune.com/2015/03/05/jury-discrimination-kleiner/|accessdate=March 6, 2015|work=Fortune|date=March 5, 2015}}</ref> of 6 women and 6 men drawn from diverse employment and ethnic backgrounds<ref name="recode-ep3">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/11/liveblog-day-three-of-ellen-pao-on-the-stand/|title=Liveblog: Day Three of Ellen Pao on the Stand|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-11|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> and Judge [[Harold E. Kahn]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/26/tech-startups-on-the-stand-z-a-a-r-l-y-z-u-o-r-a-and-t-u-m-b-l-r/|title=Ellen Pao Lawsuit: Tech Startups on the Stand - Re/code|work=Re/code}}</ref> at [[San Francisco Superior Court]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/23/technology/ellen-pao-suit-against-kleiner-perkins-heads-to-trial-with-big-potential-implications.html|title=Ellen Pao Suit Against Kleiner Perkins Heads to Trial with Big Potential Implications|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2015-03-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27592432/opening-arguments-ellen-pao-vs-kleiner-perkins-touch |title=Ellen Pao vs. Kleiner Perkins: Opening arguments touch on sex, power and money - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-06}}</ref> Kleiner Perkins was principally represented by [[Lynne Hermle]] of [[Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe]]. It was also supported by Jessica Perry of the same firm and by its own counsel Paul Vronsky.<ref name=RC032515 /> Pao was represented by Alan Exelrod of Rudy Exelrod Zieff & Lowe<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/02/24/ellen-pao-trial-kleiner-perkins-discrimination-silicon-valley-venture-capital/23908291/ |title=Ellen Pao lawyer: Kleiner Perkins 'not a level playing field' |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2015-02-26 |accessdate=2015-03-06}}</ref> and by Therese Lawless of Lawless & Lawless.<ref name = lawless >{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/25/all-male-ski-trip-and-no-women-at-al-gore-dinner-kleiners-chien-takes-the-stand-in-pao-lawsuit/|title=Ellen Pao Lawsuit Day 2 - Re/code|work=Re/code}}</ref>
It was a trial to a [[jury]] of 12 who, under the rules of the court, were permitted to submit written questions to witnesses. The judge was also permitted to question witnesses. Witnesses were disclosed and [[Deposition (law)|deposed]] prior to the trial and transcripts of their depositions were available to counsel for the opposing sides and could be compared to the testimony of the witness in the courtroom. There were hundreds of [[exhibit (legal)|exhibits]] consisting of documents and emails which the court had audio-visual equipment to display to the witness, jury, and audience.
===Plaintiff's case=== The plaintiff presented her case first, arguing that men were promoted ahead of women, that ideas coming from women were more quickly dismissed and that women who experienced sexual harassment received little support. Pao claimed that Ajit Nazre, the partner who initiated a sexual relationship with her, was responsible for much of this harassment. Pao said that he began excluding her from important meetings and emails after she ended the relationship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/ellen-pao-testifies-in-silicon-valley-gender-bias-trial/article23374197/|title=Ellen Pao testifies in Silicon Valley gender-bias trial|first=Robert|last=Burnson|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=2015-03-09|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> To characterize the company's response, her case explained that $22,000 was deducted from his paycheck once and that there was no strong desire to reprimand him until an outside investigation was able to link him to multiple instances of harassment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/03/02/ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins-ted-schlein-cocky/24267571/|title=Man Ellen Pao accused of retaliation had bonus docked|first=Elizabeth|last=Wiese|publisher=USA Today|date=2015-03-02|accessdate=2015-03-06}}</ref> Additionally Pao said that she felt the need to move from green tech to the digital division to avoid him. Pao was asked if she objected to having Nazre's office moved to the same corridor as her own. However, she claimed that when she said "yes", the company responded by trying to move her office rather than cancelling the move of Nazre's.<ref name="recode9" />
It was explained that Pao sourced an investment in [[RPX Corporation]], a company designed to fight [[patent trolls]], which led to an [[IPO]]. While arguing that this was adequate reason for a promotion, her side disputed KPCB's rationale for keeping her off the board of directors.<ref name="owns">{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/09/ellen-pao-owns-the-room/|title=Ellen Pao "Owns The Room"|first=Colleen|last=Taylor|publisher=TechCrunch|date=2015-03-09|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> They argued that the policies for how many investments and how many board seats could involve junior partners were unevenly applied between women and men. Performance reviews were raised to show contradictory evaluations such as "too bold" and "too quiet".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2015/03/29/ellen-pao-trial-recap/|title=5 things we learned about Silicon Valley culture from the Ellen Pao Trial|first=Patrick|last=Kulp|publisher=Mashable|date=2015-03-29|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> As further evidence that Pao's work for the company was not appreciated, they pointed to potential investments in Twitter and [[The Climate Corporation]] which were turned down after Pao proposed them, both of which were seen to be profitable later on.<ref name="RCMM" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/03/24/ellen-pao-wanted-kleiner-perkins-to-invest-in-twitter-in-2008-kleiner-perkins-passed/|title=Ellen Pao wanted Kleiner Perkins to invest in Twitter in 2008|first=Mark|last=Sullivan|publisher=Venture Beat|date=2015-03-24|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref>
A number of incidents were described in the plaintiff's case including a [[Valentine's day]] gift that she considered inappropriate, a conversation in a company jet that she felt objectified women, a dinner in [[Al Gore]]'s apartment to which no women were invited and a ski trip which invited one woman on a technicality.<ref name="wired18" /><ref name="recode25">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/25/all-male-ski-trip-and-no-women-at-al-gore-dinner-kleiners-chien-takes-the-stand-in-pao-lawsuit/|title=All-male ski trip and no women at Al Gore dinner: Kleiner's Chien takes the stand in Pao lawsuit|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-02-25|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> Pao stated that she did not speak out about these when they occurred because she did not want a "reputation as a complainer".<ref name="recode13">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/13/liveblog-ellen-pao-answers-questions-from-the-jury/|title=Liveblog: Ellen Pao Answers Questions From The Jury|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-13|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> Issues with her last year at Kleiner Perkins concerned a memorandum she sent on January 4, 2012 and an alleged absence of training and policies to prevent discrimination. The plaintiff argued that the defendant took several steps to cover up aspects that reflected poorly on its record of gender equality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainenewsonline.com/content/15023052-there-was-no-distribution-gender-discrimination-policy-until|title=There was no distribution of gender discrimination policy until 2012, says Kleiner Perkins|first=Julia|last=Hawkins|publisher=Maine News|date=2015-02-27|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref>
===Defendant's case=== The defendant's case placed emphasis on its large ratio of women compared to other venture capital firms. An example statistic was that it had 11 female partners and a 20% female staff compared to the average of 7-11% based on studies in 2011 and 2013.<ref name="EP KP face off">{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27561160/former-vc-ellen-pao-and-powerhouse-firm-kleiner?source=pkg|title=Ellen Pao, Kleiner Perkins face off in $16M sex discrimination trial|work=San Jose Mercury News|author=Heather Somerville|date=20 February 2015|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2012/05/female-partners-venture-capital-firms-fem-kleiner-perkins/ |title=The Depressing Gender Gap at the Nation's Top 71 Venture Capital Firms|first1=Kelly|last1=Faircloth|first2=Adrianne|last2=Jeffries|publisher=Observer |date=2012-05-31 |accessdate=2015-03-06}}</ref> A 2014 study found that this number dropped to 4% when only senior partners were considered.<ref name="senior-4-100">{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2014/02/06/venture-capitals-stunning-lack-of-female-decision-makers/|title=Venture capital's stunning lack of female decision-makers|first=Dan|last=Primack|publisher=Fortune|date=2014-02-06|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> The defense also argued that Pao was paid more than most of her male colleagues. While salaries had previously been redacted from legal documents, the trial revealed that Pao's salary after bonuses eventually reached a peak of $560,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/26/follow-the-money-did-men-make-quintuple-what-women-made-at-kleiner-perkins/|title=Follow the Money: Did Men Earn Quintuple What Women Made at Kleiner Perkins?|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-02-26|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> They also pointed to several opportunities that were afforded to Pao including a speech coach, mentorship from John Doerr and a longer career than that of many other junior partners.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/12/technology/kleiner-perkins-portrays-ellen-pao-as-combative-and-resentful-in-sex-bias-trial.html|title=Kleiner Perkins Portrays Ellen Pao as Combative and Resentful in Sex Bias Trial|first=David|last=Streitfeld|publisher=The New York Times|date=2015-03-11|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> To argue that Pao's firing was justified, they presented several negative performance reviews that she received and frequently described her as "entitled" and "not a team player".<ref name="wired18">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/kleiner-putting-ellen-paos-personality-trial/|title=Kleiner is Putting Ellen Pao's Personality on Trial|first=Davey|last=Alba|publisher=Wired|date=2015-03-18|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref>
Kleiner Perkins contended that Pao's job description had been mostly managerial and that limiting her involvement in investing was not a sign of discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/02/24/ellen-pao-trial-kleiner-perkins-discrimination-silicon-valley-venture-capital/23908291/|title=Ellen Pao lawyer: Kleiner Perkins 'not a level playing field'|first=Elizabeth|last=Weise|publisher=USA Today|date=2015-02-26|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> They also said that promotions to the senior partner position were rare with 20 of the 25 people previously in Pao's position also being passed over.<ref name="Doerr testifies">{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27645378/jurors-ellen-pao-discrimination-case-question-key-witness?source=pkg|title=Ellen Pao trial: Doerr says tech, VC firms would do better 'if they hired more women'|work=San Jose Mercury News|author=Heather Somerville|date=4 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> The defense brought in emails to show that Pao expected to be fired and suggested that some of them provided evidence that she was plotting a lawsuit.<ref name="recode11">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/11/an-alternate-narrative-of-ellen-pao-emerges-under-cross-examination/|title=An Alternative Narrative of Ellen Pao Emerges Under Cross-Examination|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-11|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> They also argued over whether her acceptance of [[severance package|severance pay]] constituted a tacit approval that the company was within its rights to fire her. The package was potentially valued at $400,000 but Pao did not receive the full amount on account of finding a job within less than a year.<ref name="liveblog4" /> There are also reports that she turned it down entirely.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/suzanne-lucas/why-everyone-looks-bad-in-the-ellen-pao-case.html|title=Why everyone looks bad in the Ellen Pao case|first=Suzanne|last=Lucas|publisher=Inc|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Stating that many of the plaintiff's [[statute of limitations|claims were stale]], KPCB's side offered some explanations for the incidents she described and alleged that she saw discrimination where none existed.<ref name=RC032415/> They claimed that this provided further evidence that she was an unpleasant coworker.
The defendant tried to introduce another line of argument based on Pao having a financial motive for filing the lawsuit. They stated in a [[Sidebar (law)|sidebar]] that she may have done this to help alleviate the financial troubles of her husband [[Buddy Fletcher]], a hedge fund manager who filed for bankruptcy in 2012. However, Judge Harold Kahn ruled out this defence stating that it would place undue scrutiny on the plaintiff's personal life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/12/judge-denies-kleiner-perkins-bid-to-discuss-ellen-paos-financial-motives-in-court/|title=Judge Denies Kleiner Perkins' Bid To Discuss Ellen Pao's Financial Motives In Court|first=Colleen|last=Taylor|publisher=TechCrunch|date=2015-03-12|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> Additionally, Pao maintained that their money had always been separate due to a [[prenuptial agreement]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plainsite.org/dockets/download.html?id=215062716&z=d0d40f4c|title=Opposition to Plaintiff's Motion to Strike and Tax Defendant's Costs|publisher=Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe|date=2015-06-05|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> At the time, Fletcher was reading news about the trial and not making courtroom appearances, on the advice of Pao and her lawyers.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Reset.html?id=pBdVDgAAQBAJ|title=Reset: My fight for inclusion and lasting change|first=Ellen|last=Pao|publisher=Spiegel & Grau|year=2017|accessdate=2017-11-25}}</ref>
===Testimony=== While most of the witnesses had some affiliation with Kleiner Perkins, many of them had left the firm by the time the trial took place. Some witnesses, such as John Doerr, were called by both the plaintiff and defense lawyers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/04/a-star-witness-for-both-sides-somehow-john-doerr-makes-both-ellen-pao-and-kleiner-perkins-look-good/|title=A Star Witness for Both Sides? Somehow John Doerr Makes Both Ellen Pao and Kleiner Perkins Look Good|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-04|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Exelrod began by showing pictures of three male witnesses, Amol Deshpande, Chi-Hua Chien and Wen Hsieh, saying that they were promoted ahead of Pao despite joining the firm later and not investing in any companies that went public.<ref name="recode24">{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes|title=VCs in Bathrobes, Women Asked to Play Secretary, Angry Texts: Day One of Pao v. Kleiner Perkins|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/24/vcs-in-bathrobes-women-asked-to-play-secretary-and-angry-texts-day-one-of-pao-v-kleiner-perkins/|accessdate=March 8, 2015|work=[[Re/code]]|date=February 24, 2015}}</ref> Hermle countered that other men not shown were not promoted and that those three were seen as assets because they had started businesses before being hired.
The first witness called was Tracy "Trae" Vassallo who agreed to testify despite remembering a conversation in which Pao called her "untrustworthy". Her appearance was described as a surprise.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/3/3/8141053/ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins-venture-capital|title=The Ellen Pao trial is spilling Silicon Valley secrets|first=Natasha|last=Tiku|publisher=The Verge|date=2015-03-03|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Having received a promotion to senior partner after Pao's termination, Vassallo testified that she still enjoyed working for KPCB but had problems with Chien and Nazre. About Nazre, she said he accosted her while in a bath robe and propositioned her at a dinner after lying that it would involve other contacts of theirs. She testified that her boss Ray Lane told her that she "should be flattered" by his advances and asked her to "talk to her husband" before deciding what to do. Lane denied making the former comment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-03/kleiner-s-lane-tells-jury-partner-won-promotion-after-sex-affair|title=Kleiner's Lane tells jury partner won promotion after affair|first1=Karen|last1=Gullo|first2=Eric|last2=Newcomer|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2015-03-02|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Along with explaining that she confided in Pao and filed the complaint which eventually led to Nazre's termination, Vassallo mentioned the seating plan of a meeting in which she and Pao were told to sit in the back. Her description was "it sounds petty, but people were arranged in the room around how much input they'd have in the discussion."<ref name="recode24" />
The second witness was Chi-Hua Chien who confirmed that he organized the ski trip and the Al Gore dinner, both of which had only male guests. For the ski trip, he said this was done to ease the logistics of condo sharing and that if the trip were repeated in another year, it would have involved more women to make up for this. He denied the plaintiff's claim that he said "women kill the buzz." Regarding the dinner, a deposition video was brought up in which [[Aileen Lee]] testified that she and John Doerr complained about the lack of women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27444497/ellen-pao-seeking-16-million-sex-discrimination-lawsuit|title=Ellen Pao seeking $16 million in sex discrimination lawsuit against Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers|first=Heather|last=Somerville|publisher=Mercury News|date=2015-02-02|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Pao said she felt humiliated because she lived in the building where the event was being held and had to explain to the guests passing by that she was not one of them.<ref name="owns" /> Pao's side presented emails that showed Chien complaining about her in a vulgar way. Chien stated that he was collegial at first and only developed problems with Pao later on. The defense also argued that Chien would not have been named as a trustee of Lee's firm Cowboy Ventures if his respect for women had been doubted.<ref name="recode25" />
Kleiner Perkins CFO Susan Biglieri testified that Mary Meeker and Beth Seidenberg were the first two women in the firm's history to reach its highest rank of "managing member". Pao's legal team argued that these promotions in 2011 and 2012 were made to save face in the wake of Pao's discrimination complaints.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/02/ellen-pao-trial-kleiner-perkins-says-didnt-distribute-gender-discrimination-policy-2012/|title=Kleiner Perkins says it didn't distribute gender discrimination policy until 2012|first=Davey|last=Alba|publisher=Wired|date=2015-02-26|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Biglieri also testified that the firm's anti-discrimination policy, though distributed internally, was not posted on the website until after Ellen Pao filed her lawsuit. The plaintiff also showed that an Equal Opportunity Employment policy had to be written in 2012 after COO Eric Keller failed to find one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/12/kleiner-perkins-wrote-an-hr-policy-in-wake-of-female-partner-complaints/|title=Kleiner Perkins Wrote HR Policy After Female Partner Complaints|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-12|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref>
Rejecting claims that she was hired into an operating role, Pao explained that she initially turned down the job offer from Kleiner Perkins but arranged with John Doerr to make it "more senior".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/when-kleiner-perkins-first-offered-ellen-pao-a-job-she-turned-it-down-2015-3|title=When Kleiner Perkins first offered Ellen Pao a job, she turned it down|first=Sam|last=Colt|publisher=Business Insider|date=2015-03-09|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Some of Pao's duties included reviewing 1,800 [[iFund]] applications, writing part of Mary Meeker's USA Inc report and ghostwriting many of Doerr's speeches including a [[TED Talk]].<ref name="recode9" /><ref name="RCMM">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/16/liveblog-mary-meeker-testifies-in-paokleiner-perkins-case/|title=Liveblog: Mary Meeker Testifies in Pao/Kleiner Perkins Case|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-16|accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> Doerr testified that he praised Pao's writing skills from her date of hiring but only learned that she resented this work much later.<ref name="doerr2">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/04/john-doerr-testifies-in-pao-vs-kleiner-perkins-day-two-liveblog/|title=John Doerr Testifies in Pao vs Kleiner Perkins: Day Two Liveblog|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-04|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Doerr also recalled that before convincing her to stay, Pao wanted to leave in 2007 due to frustration with Ajit Nazre. Another of Pao's attempts to leave was protested by Ted Schlein, her boss after Doerr. Although Schlein testified that he "reluctantly" hired Pao, he also said that he convinced her to stay at the firm when she was being considered for one of the original jobs in [[Google Ventures]]. Schlein's testimony covered reviews that were frequently critical of Pao, using "entitled", "passive" and "territorial" to describe her. He was criticized for a comment that venture capital skills were "not part of Ellen's genetic makeup."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/02/27/a-performance-review-that-changed-dramatically-and-paos-400000-severance-package-pao-v-kleiner-perkins-trial/|title=Performance Review Rewrites and Pao's 'Genetic Makeup': Pao vs Kleiner Perkins Trial Day 4|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-02-27|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Doerr claimed that he frequently defended Pao and advocated for the reviews to be rewritten until eventually supporting her termination. He said "the junior partner is an up-or-out role. We have no lifetime junior partners." When Hermle presented a list of female partners to Doerr, he described playing a role in all of their careers. However, Exelrod argued that Doerr was responsible for some sexism as well by playing a video where he stated that "white male nerds" were a safe investment.<ref name="doerr2" /> Although Pao spoke positively of Doerr, she commented that he often raised issues of pregnancy and suggested that her three-month maternity leave was the real reason she did not receive a board seat at RPX.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2015/03/reddit-ceo-ellen-pao-harassment-complaints-fell-on-deaf-ears-at-kleiner-perkins/|title=Reddit CEO Ellen Pao: Harassment complaints fell on deaf ears at Kleiner Perkins|first=Megan|last=Geuss|publisher=ArsTechnica|date=2015-03-09|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Doerr stated that having junior partners sit on only one board was a guideline, not a rule.<ref name="doerr1">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/03/kleiner-perkins-john-doerr-takes-the-stand-in-pao-case-liveblog/|title=Kleiner Perkins' John Doerr Takes the Stand in Pao Case: Liveblog|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-03|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Pao contended that Chien had "five or six" board seats as a junior<ref name="recode13" /> but the defense replied that he may have shortened "board observer seat" to "board seat" as a form of bragging and stated that Matt Murphy took five years to join a board.<ref name=RC032415/>
Testimony of the plaintiff occupied most of the second week. She described mentoring Wen Hsieh and recalled hearing about three administrative assistants who were harassed by Nazre. When questioned about this, Pao knew only that one of their first names was Tina, inviting theories that the women had settled with Kleiner Perkins and signed non-disclosure agreements.<ref name="recode20">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/20/ellen-pao-and-the-case-of-the-mysterious-missing-admins/|title=Ellen Pao and the Case of the Mysterious Missing Admins|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-20|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> On [[cross-examination]], Hermle found an inconsistency with Pao's deposition video on the question of whether she asked to see an Equal Opportunity Employment policy.<ref name="recode-ep2" /> She also sought to show evidence of plotting in 2011 and 2012 by bringing up emails in which Pao discussed her options with friend and Google engineer Lori Park. These revealed that Pao had applied for jobs at [[YouTube]] and [[Menlo Ventures]] and was considering starting her own firm.<ref name="recode-ep3" /> Some issues with how Pao responded to termination were also raised. Pao said that it made sense for her to break the news to the CEOs of the three companies in her immediate network but revealed that Ted Schlein chastised her for doing so.<ref name=liveblog4 /> On the stand, Pao objected to the way [[Employment Law Alliance]] investigator Stephen Hirschfeld responded to the discrimination complaints by Trae Vassallo and herself. She alleged that the reports used biased language, softened the airplane incident by changing the name of a pornographic show to ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]'' and focused on eliminating KPCB's liability rather than addressing the concerns of employees.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2015/03/ellen-pao-answers-jury-questions-frankly-in-gender-discrimination-case/|title=Ellen Pao answers jury questions frankly in gender discrimination case|first=Megan|last=Geuss|publisher=ArsTechnica|date=2015-03-13|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> When Hirschfeld was questioned by Lawless, he revealed that his reports did not include a matrix which Vassallo used to tabulate discrepancies between male and female partners.<ref name=WP032415 /> This criticism was repeated by Allison West of Employment Practices Specialists who testified that the firm's investigation of gender issues was insufficient. She also commented that it was circular for the defendant to rely heavily on performance reviews to discredit Pao's allegations against the people writing them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/16/expert-slams-kleiner-perkins-investigation-into-paos-allegations/|title=Expert Slams Kleiner Perkins' Investigation Into Pao's Allegations|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-16|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref>
Contrasting Pao's statement that she discussed gender bias with Aileen Lee and Trae Vassallo, the defendant named three female witnesses who stated that they never felt discriminated against: Mary Meeker, Beth Seidenberg and Juliet de Baubigny.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27779413/kleiner-perkins-discrimination-trial-nears-end-closing-arguments|title=Closing arguments in Ellen Pao case: 'They ran Kleiner Perkins like a boys club'|first=Heather|last=Somerville|publisher=Mercury News|date=2015-03-24|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Private human resources consultant Rhoma Young defended the attention to detail in KPCB's review process and Harvard Business School professor [[The Money of Invention|Paul Gompers]] spoke favorably of its commitment to diversity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/gender-problem-venture-capital-really-really-bad/|title=The Gender Problem in Venture Capital is Really, Really Bad|first=Davey|last=Alba|publisher=Wired|date=2015-03-20|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref><ref name="Wired-Too_Opinionated">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/kleiner-keeps-trying-butcher-paos-claims/|title=Kleiner Witness Says Ellen Pao Was 'a Bit Too Opinionated'|work=Wired Magazine|author=Davey Alba|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref> Another professor testifying for Kleiner Perkins, David Lewin of UCLA, alleged that Pao's claim to $16 million was invalid because she could have secured a lucrative salary with a more thorough job search.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/03/16/ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins-alison-west/24782815/|title=Mary Meeker: No discrimination at Kleiner Perkins|first=Elizabeth|last=Weise|publisher=USA Today|date=2015-03-16|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> When Mary Meeker testified, she described Pao as "insecure" and "quiet" and recalled being invited to a second Al Gore dinner.<ref name="RCMM" /> Beth Seidenberg compared venture capital to her background in the medical field and said she was optimistic that it would see an influx of female talent as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/21/pao-vs-kleiner-defense-rests-its-case-showcasing-a-different-side-of-the-story/|title=Pao Vs. Kleiner Defense Rests Its Case, Showcasing A Different Side Of The Story|first=Colleen|last=Taylor|publisher=TechCrunch|date=2015-03-21|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Juliet de Baubigny testified more directly about Ellen Pao and condemned her habit of making complaints against coworkers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/pao-vs-kleiner-perkins-lawsuit-lawyers-called-to-the-stand-2015-3|title=Things get weird at the Ellen Pao trial as her side braces for the worst|first=Matt|last=Weinberger|publisher=Business Insider|date=2015-03-20|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> She also denied using the word "sex addict" to describe Ajit Nazre, something that the plaintiff cited as evidence that his hostility was common knowledge.<ref name="recode20" />
Testifying in the final week was an investor witness from outside Kleiner Perkins named Andrew Jody Gessow, a passenger of the private flight that Pao described as offensive. He claimed that there was no discussion of pornography but Lawless pressed that his memory may have lapsed due to medication he was taking.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/03/18/ellen-pao-randy-komisar-kleiner-perkins/24936023/|title=Ellen Pao trial testimony returns to that plane ride|first=Elizabeth|last=Weise|publisher=USA Today|date=2015-03-18|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Senior partner Randy Komisar also testified that week about why he received the board seat at RPX despite his investment in it being a joint effort with Ellen Pao. He stated that Pao described her respect for John Doerr's decision in an email and interpreted that as meaning she agreed with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2015/03/17/kleiner-perkins-ellen-pao/|title=Kleiner Perkins partner gave Ellen Pao a book of sexual poetry because he 'felt guilty'|first=Patrick|last=Kulp|publisher=Mashable|date=2015-03-17|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Komisar said that his friendship with Pao deteriorated over the word "hate" when she wrote in a later email that the board of RPX "hated him". He also testified that a book described as making Pao feel uneasy was a Valentine's day gift from him. Specifically it was the ''[[Book of Longing]]'' by [[Leonard Cohen]] with whom Pao claimed to be unfamiliar.<ref name="recode11" /> One of the last people to testify was senior partner Matt Murphy who described Pao as "pushy" and "aggressive".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/03/18/kleiner-perkins-ellen-pao-murphy/|title=In sexism trial, Kleiner Perkins partner says Ellen Pao needed to go|first=Kia|last=Kokalitcheva|publisher=Fortune|date=2015-03-18|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> He also recalled being embarrassed when Pao fell asleep at a board meeting. Although admitting that he began taking detailed notes about Pao four days after her suit was filed, he maintained that he had wanted to fire her for years and that only resistance from Doerr stood in the way.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/18/how-kleiner-perkins-matt-murphy-fired-ellen-pao/|title=How Kleiner Perkins' Matt Murphy Fired Ellen Pao|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-18|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref> Discussing a negative performance review, Exelrod asked Murphy to explain why Pao was able to receive high praise from [[Mike McCue]]. Murphy's response was that McCue was known for saying overly positive things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/19/kleiners-matt-murphy-on-why-pao-failed-as-a-vc/|title=Kleiner's Matt Murphy on why Ellen Pao failed as a VC|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-19|accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref>
===Jury instructions=== The jury was reminded of the plaintiff's claims in which number 1 had to be proven before number 3 could be considered:<ref name=RC032415/> #Kleiner Perkins discriminated against Ellen Pao because of her gender. #Kleiner Perkins retaliated against her because of conversations in December 2011 and her memorandum in January 2012. #Kleiner Perkins failed to take all reasonable steps to prevent discrimination against her. #Kleiner Perkins retaliated by firing her after her conversations and memorandum. There were no sexual harassment claims.<ref name=RC032415/> The standard of proof was [[preponderance of the evidence]],<ref name=RC032415/> met if a proposition is [[Probability|more likely]] to be true than not.
Despite the title of "junior partner," Ellen Pao was an [[At-will employment|at-will employee]] who could be fired without warning at any time for any reason or for no reason but not for the wrong reasons such as a [[At-will employment#Public policy exceptions|statutory exception]] where "actions or inactions were substantially motivated by gender discrimination and/or retaliation". "Substantial motivating reasons and factors are more than remote or trivial motivating reasons and factors."<ref name=RC032415>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes and Nellie Bowles|title=Live: Closing Arguments in Ellen Pao's Gender Discrimination Case Against Kleiner Perkins|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/24/live-closing-arguments-in-ellen-paos-gender-discrimination-case-against-kleiner-perkins/|accessdate=March 24, 2015|work=Re/code|date=March 24, 2015}}</ref>
It was explained that compensatory damages are an estimate of the plaintiff's past and future lost earnings. Other, more complicated and technical, compensatory damages were reserved for future determination in the event of a favorable verdict for plaintiff.<ref name=RC032415/>
If the jury felt the defendant's actions involved malice, fraud and oppression they could have considered punitive damages after the initial verdict was returned. There was a 7-page verdict form.<ref name=RC032415/>
===Closing arguments=== Alan Exelrod made the [[closing argument]] for plaintiff, saying that the defendant's leaders "ran Kleiner Perkins like a boys' club." Lynne Hermle made the closing statement for defendant, focusing on the issues of the numbers of women employed and the allegedly discriminatory events.<ref name=RC032415/> According to her, the plaintiff was fired because, while she is an excellent executive, she was not able to perform in venture capital at a senior level. Therese Lawless presented the rebuttal on behalf of the plaintiff, saying "women will be judged in one way and men in another. That's not how it works in this country."<ref name=RC032515>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes and Nellie Bowles|title=Live: Day Two of the Ellen Pao v. Kleiner Perkins Case Summations|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/25/live-day-two-of-the-ellen-pao-v-kleiner-perkins-case-summations/|accessdate=March 25, 2015|work=Re/code|date=March 25, 2015}}</ref> She also thanked an anonymous member of the jury whose question revealed that an evaluation, deemed to be negative based on its long comments from Matt Murphy and Ted Schlein, actually received input from 7 people, 5 of whom reviewed Pao positively.<ref name=RC032515 />
===Submission and verdict=== The case was submitted to the jury about noon on March 25, 2015.<ref name=RC032515/> A unanimous verdict was not required, only support of 9 of the 12 jurors, 75%.<ref name=WP032415>{{cite news|author1=Andrea Peterson|title=The sex discrimination trial that rocked Silicon Valley is almost over. Here's what you need to know.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2015/03/24/the-sex-discrimination-trial-that-rocked-silicon-valley-is-almost-over-heres-what-you-need-to-know/|accessdate=March 25, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=March 24, 2015|quote=If the jury rules in favor of Kleiner Perkins, Pao will get nothing. To issue a verdict, nine jurors out of 12 must agree on whether or not there was discrimination.}}</ref> It was reported that when deliberations began, impressions of the jurors were 8 siding with Kleiner Perkins, 2 siding with Ellen Pao and 2 undecided with all groups split evenly by gender.<ref name="recode30">{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/30/a-juror-speaks-about-his-vote-for-kleiner-perkins-but-still-wants-the-firm-to-be-punished/|title=A Juror Speaks About His Vote for Kleiner Perkins but Still Wants the Firm to 'Be Punished'|first1=Liz|last1=Gannes|first2=Nellie|last2=Bowles|publisher=Recode|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref>
The initial verdict was announced shortly after 2 p.m. on Friday, March 27. The jury found 10-2 in favor of Kleiner Perkins on the first 3 claims. The jury, which found 8 to 4 in favor of Kleiner Perkins on the fourth claim of retaliation by termination, was directed to continue to deliberate as the finding did not meet the required threshold of 75%. The jury deliberated for about two hours then returned a final verdict in favor of Kleiner Perkins on all claims as one juror changed his vote from yes to no on the 4th claim.<ref name=Recodeverdict>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes and Nellie Bowles|title=Live: Ellen Pao Loses on All Claims in Historic Gender Discrimination Lawsuit Against Kleiner Perkins|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/27/live-the-pao-v-kleiner-perkins-verdict/|accessdate=March 27, 2015|work=Re/code|date=March 27, 2015|quote=That's the full verdict. No on all claims.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327235113/https://recode.net/2015/03/27/live-the-pao-v-kleiner-perkins-verdict/|archivedate=March 27, 2015|df=}}</ref> According to the three jurors who talked to the media the jury focused on Pao's performance reviews in arriving at their verdict.<ref name=Reuters42415/>
On the same day, jurors Steve Sammut and Marshallette Ramsey revealed what their votes had been. Ramsey supported the plaintiff and said that she encouraged other women in Pao's situation to stand up for themselves. Her reason was that it "seemed that the men, with the same character flaws that Ellen was cited with, were able to propel and continue."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/27/two-jurors-on-opposite-sides-share-their-pao-vs-kleiner-perspectives/|title=Two Jurors On Opposite Sides Share Their Pao Vs. Kleiner Perspectives|first=Alexia|last=Tsotsis|publisher=TechCrunch|date=2015-03-27|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref> Although Sammut was not convinced that what Pao experienced was gender discrimination, he expressed a hope that Kleiner Perkins would still be punished for how it treated employees in general.<ref name="recode30" />
===Costs and appeal=== The defendant requested [[court costs|costs]] of $972,814, 90% of which was for expert witness fees. Kleiner Perkins stated that the fee would be waived if the plaintiff chose not to [[appeal]].<ref name=Reuters42415>{{cite news|author1=Dan Levine and Jim Christie|title=UPDATE 4-Kleiner Perkins seeks almost $1 mln in costs in Pao case|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/23/kleiner-lawsuit-idUSL1N0XK2K720150423|accessdate=April 24, 2015|work=Reuters|date=April 24, 2015|quote=Kleiner's offer to withdraw its costs request in exchange for an end to the case, is common when defendants prevail in employment lawsuits}}</ref> On June 18, 2015<ref name=Recode6415a>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gainnes|title=Why Did Ellen Pao File to Appeal? Here's One Expensive Reason.|url=http://recode.net/2015/06/04/why-did-ellen-pao-file-to-appeal-heres-one-expensive-reason/|accessdate=June 5, 2015|work=Re/code|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> the court awarded $275,966 to Kleiner Perkins, stating that the disparity in economic resources between the parties was too great to justify the original amount.<ref name=Recode61815>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gannes|title='Court of Public Opinion' Has Ruled Against Tech's Diversity Record, Says John Doerr|url=http://recode.net/2015/06/18/court-of-public-opinion-has-ruled-against-techs-diversity-record-says-john-doerr/|accessdate=June 19, 2015|work=Re/code|date=June 18, 2015|quote=awarded $276,000 in costs}}</ref> Pao's side claimed that this was an unfair response to a loss in a discrimination case and filed a notice of appeal on June 1, 2015, 7 days before the deadline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/08/11/pao-appeals-trial-costs/|title=Ellen Pao appeals order to pay Kleiner Perkins trial costs|first=Kia|last=Kocalitcheva|publisher=Fortune|date=2015-08-11|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref> The appeal, which would have been held in the First District Court of Appeal, was to focus on the verdict since most procedural rulings by the judge were made in favor of the plaintiff.<ref name=Recode6115>{{cite news|author1=Liz Gainnes|title=Ellen Pao Plans to Appeal|url=http://recode.net/2015/06/01/ellen-pao-plans-to-appeal/|accessdate=June 2, 2015|work=Re/code|date=June 1, 2015|quote=Employment lawyers and court watchers had noted Judge Harold Kahn attempted to make the jury's decision airtight by largely rejecting the Kleiner legal team's objections and procedural requests throughout the trial.}}</ref>
On September 10, 2015, sources reported that Pao was dropping her appeal, citing an inability to afford further litigation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/09/10/439232954/ellen-pao-former-reddit-ceo-drops-appeal-in-gender-discrimination-lawsuit.|title=Ex-Reddit CEO Ellen Pao Drops Appeal In Gender-Bias Suit Against Kleiner Perkins|first=Eyder|last=Peralta|publisher=NPR|date=2015-09-10|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/3c6eb39c79634bc090636db988d879ed/woman-who-lost-silicon-valley-gender-bias-suit-drops-appeal|title=Woman who lost Silicon Valley bias suit is dropping appeal|publisher=Associated Press|first=Sudhin|last=Thanawala|date=2015-09-10|accessdate=2015-10-16}}</ref> In a [[Re/code]] post on the topic, Pao wrote about the importance of discussing gender bias publicly and stated that she was rejecting requests from KPCB to sign a non-disparagement agreement. She stated that this would make her responsible for court costs after the appeal was dropped.<ref name=Recode91015>{{cite news|author1=Kara Swisher|title=Ellen Pao: 'I Have Decided to End My Lawsuit Against Kleiner Perkins'|url=http://recode.net/2015/09/10/ellen-pao-i-have-decided-to-end-my-lawsuit-against-kleiner-perkins/|accessdate=September 11, 2015|work=RE/code|date=September 10, 2015|quote=$276,000 in legal fees}}</ref> However, on September 17, Kleiner Perkins accepted the dropping of Pao's appeal without the $276,000 cost reimbursement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/done-deal-ellen-pao-doesnt-have-to-pay-kleiner-perkins/|title=Done Deal: Ellen Pao doesn't have to pay Kleiner Perkins' legal fees|first=Terry|last=Collins|publisher=CNET|date=2015-09-23|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref>
==Significance== Following the case, a number of other people filed discrimination suits against high-profile companies, as with ''[[Chia Hong v. Facebook]]'' and ''Tina Huang v. Twitter''.<ref name="Huang v Twitter">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Marisa|title=Ellen Pao is 'a Rosa Parks' for women in Silicon Valley|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/3/30/ellen-paos-effects-on-women-in-tech.html|accessdate=16 September 2015|publisher=Al Jazeera America|date=March 30, 2015|location=New York City, New York}}</ref> A number of publications credited Pao and her case with focusing attention on the issue of gender discrimination and workplace sexism, especially in the venture capital and technology industries, and for inspiring others to act.<ref name=NYTDisrupter>{{cite news|author1=Farhad Manjoo|title=Ellen Pao Disrupts How Silicon Valley Does Business|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/28/technology/ellen-pao-disrupts-how-silicon-valley-does-business.html|accessdate=March 28, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 27, 2015|quote=Ms. Klein argued that the Kleiner trial would become a landmark case for women in the workplace, as consequential for corporate gender relations as Anita Hill's accusations in 1991 of sexual harassment during the confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas}}</ref><ref name=NYT032715>{{cite news|author1=David Streitfeld|title=Ellen Pao Loses Silicon Valley Gender Bias Case Against Kleiner Perkins|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/28/technology/ellen-pao-kleiner-perkins-case-decision.html|accessdate=March 27, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 27, 2015|quote=In a sign that the struggle over the place of women in Silicon Valley is only beginning, gender discrimination suits have recently been filed against two prominent companies, Facebook and Twitter.}}</ref><ref name=RecodeDecker>{{cite news|author1=Sue Decker|authorlink1=Susan Decker|title=A Fish Is the Last to Discover Water: Impressions From the Ellen Pao Trial|url=http://recode.net/2015/03/26/a-fish-is-the-last-to-discover-water-impressions-from-the-ellen-pao-trial/|accessdate=March 28, 2015|work=Re/code|date=March 26, 2015|quote=We may look back at this as a watershed moment — regardless of how the very attentive jury comes out on their verdict.}}</ref> The impact of Pao and the case became known as "the Pao effect".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/04/08/silicon-valley-pao-effect/|title=Silicon Valley lawyers: We're already seeing a 'Pao effect'|work=Fortune|first=Vivian|last=Giang|date=2015-04-08|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/the-pao-effect-silicon-valleys-biggest-discrimination-case-is-already-inspirin|title=The Pao Effect: Silicon Valley's Discrimination Case Is Only the Beginning|work=Motherboard|first=Kari|last=Paul|date=2015-03-25|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therecorder.com/id=1202722378745/Employment-Lawyers-Brace-for-Pao-Effect?slreturn=20150816061947|title=Employment Lawyers Brace for 'Pao Effect'|first=Marisa|last=Kendall|work=The Recorder|date=2015-04-01|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suitsbysuits.com/The-Inbox-The-Pao-Effect|title=The Inbox – The "Pao Effect"|work=Suits By Suits|first=Ashley|last=O'Neill|date=2015-04-13|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theazaragroup.com/banning-salary-negotiations-ellen-pao/|title=Banning Salary Negotiations – Kleiner Perkins'' was again credited with inspiring a discrimination case when security researcher Katie Moussouris filed a suit against [[Microsoft]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/09/microsoft-gender-lawsuit/|title=Gender bias suit will soon shine a harsh light on Microsoft|first=Issie|last=Lapowsky|publisher=Wired|date=2015-09-18|accessdate=2015-10-02}}</ref>

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Perry Hooper |state_house = Alabama |district = 73rd |term_start = January 3, 1984 |term_end = January 3, 2003 |predecessor = Ham Wilson |successor = [[David Grimes (politician)|David Grimes]] |birth_name = Perry Oliver Hooper Jr. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|10|5}} |birth_place = [[Montgomery, Alabama]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Judy McKissick |children = 3 |relatives = [[Perry O. Hooper Sr.]] {{small|(father)}} |education = [[Auburn University at Montgomery|Auburn University, Montgomery]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Faulkner University]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} }} '''Perry Oliver Hooper Jr.''' (born October 5, 1954), is an [[insurance]] agent from his native [[Montgomery, Alabama]], who is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] former member of the [[Alabama House of Representatives]], having served in the District 73 seat from 1984 until 2003. After five terms, he was defeated in the [[primary election]] held on June 4, 2002. ==Background== Hooper is the oldest of four sons of late [[Perry O. Hooper Sr.]], the former [[Chief Justice]] of the [[Alabama Supreme Court]], and the former Marilyn Yost. He received his undergraduate degree from [[Auburn University at Montgomery]] and his [[Juris Doctor]] from the [[Thomas Goode Jones School of Law]], affiliated with [[Faulkner University]], also in Montgomery. Hooper is a vice president of the Palomar Insurance Corporation. He is married to the former Judy McKissick, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Clement McKissick, formerly of Montgomery. Judy Hooper is a teacher at the [[Trinity Presbyterian School]] in Montgomery, affiliated with the Trinity [[Presbyterian Church in America|Presbyterian Church]]. Hooper is [[United Methodist]].{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/5664/perry-hooper-jr#.U2CdkstOUfg|title=Perry Hooper Jr.'s Biography|publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]]|accessdate=April 30, 2014}} The couple has three sons: (1) Perry Hooper III, [[D.O.]], who is married to Dr. Marsa True Beck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Taylor Beck of [[Richmond, VirginiaVirginia]], named for her aunt, Marsa Susan Beck of [[Jacksonville, Florida]], (2) Davis Shaw Hooper of [[Auburn, Alabama]], and (3) Thomas Clement Hooper of Montgomery.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/celebration/timesdispatch/celebrations-announcement.aspx?n=perry-oliver-hooper-iii&aid=165900764|title=Wedding Announcement: Perry Oliver Hooper, III, and Marsa True Beck, July 21, 2013|publisher=''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''|accessdate=April 30, 2014}} ==Political life== In 1982, Hooper ran for the District 81 state House seat vacated by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Larry Dixon (politician)|Larry Dixon]], who was elected to the [[Alabama State Senate]] and switched to Republican affiliation in 1984. He was narrowly defeated by another Democrat, Ham Wilson Jr., who received 7,996 votes (50.9 percent) to Hooper's 7,725 (49.1 percent). In a [[special election]] in District 73 in 1983, a result of [[redistricting]], he narrowly unseated Wilson, 4,518 (51.1 percent) to 4,328 (48.9 percent) to fill the remaining three years of the term. Hooper was unopposed for reelection in 1986 and won with 64.1 percent in 1990 over the Democrat Robert Finley. Hooper increased his margin in 1994 to 73.3 percent over another Democrat, Ray Vaughan. He won re-nomination in 1998 over fellow Republican Donald Blair Little (1954–2012), an attorney in Montgomery and a son of Republican former state Representative [[Tandy Little]]. Hooper had no Democratic opponent in 1998 for what turned out to be his last four-year term in the state House. Hooper lost in the 2002 primary to fellow Republican [[David Grimes (Alabama politician)|David Grimes]], 3,582 (52.3 percent) to 3,273 (47.8 percent). Grimes was then unopposed in the [[general election]] of 2002 but lost the Republican primary in 2008.Hooper's defeat by Grimes is attributed in part to a $12,000 fine in 2001 from the Alabama Ethics Commission.{{cite web|url=http://legacy.decaturdaily.com/decaturdaily/news/060716/loyalty.shtml|title=Candidates in GOP runoff for PSC 2 question loyalty|publisher=''Decatur Daily'', [[Decatur, Alabama]], July 16, 2006|accessdate=April 30, 2014}} Hooper was a delegate to the [[Republican National Convention|Republican national conventions]] of [[1984 Republican National Convention|1984 (Dallas)]], [[1992 Republican National Convention|1992 (Houston)]], and [[1996 Republican National Convention|1996 (San Diego)]]. He served on the Platform Committee in 1992, with the re-nomination of the [[George Herbert Walker Bush|Bush]]-[[Dan Quayle|Quayle]] ticket, and the Rules Committee in 1996, when the party turned to [[Bob Dole]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=61173|title=Hooper, Perry O. Jr.|publisher=ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=April 30, 2014}} Hooper failed in a political comeback in 2006 though he won the Republican nomination with 58 percent of the vote for the Place 2 seat on the [[Alabama Public Service Commission]] vacated by Democrat-turned Republican [[George Wallace Jr.]] Hooper defeated a former state senator, Democrat-turned-Republican [[John Amari]], a lawyer from the [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] [[suburb]] of [[Trussville, Alabama|Trussville]], to win the Republican nomination for the Public Service Commission. Hooper was thereafter defeated in the general election by the Democratic former state auditor, [[Susan Parker]], 633,584 (53.5 percent), to 550,435 (46.4 percent). Amari served twenty years in both houses of the legislature and was elected in 2008 as a judge of the Alabama 10th Judicial Circuit Court. In the 2006 campaign, Hooper called Amari a "[[Republican in Name Only|RINO]], a Republican in name only." Amari replied that Hooper "might have been born in a Republican family, but [by] his conduct ... he has 'left his raising' as they say." In 1987 at the age of thirty-three, Hooper was named "Outstanding Young Man of Alabama" by the [[Junior Chamber International]]. He received the Thomas Jefferson Free Enterprise Award from the [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] (ALEC), a group of [[Conservative (politics)|conservative]] lawmakers and businesses.{{cn|date=January 2015}} A coach of youth athletics, Hooper is a former "Man of the Year" by the [[YMCA]] of Montgomery. He is affiliated with [[Kiwanis International]], the Southern Development Council, and the [[Montgomery County, Alabama|Montgomery County]] Republican Committee. ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-al-hs}} {{s-bef|before=Ham Wilson}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[Alabama House of Representatives]]

of 1978 to provide additional procedures for authorizing certain acquisitions of foreign intelligence information and for other purposes. | colloquialacronym = PAA | nickname = | enacted by = 110th | effective date = August 5, 2007 | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-121/pdf/STATUTE-121-Pg552.pdf | cite public law = 110-55 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|121|552}} | acts amended =[[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] | acts repealed = | title amended = [[Title 50 of the United States Code|50 U.S.C.: War and National Defense]] | sections created = <!--{{USC}} can be used--> | sections amended = {{Usc-title-chap|50|36}} § 1801 et seq. | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:SN01927:@@@R | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill =
